# [ğ“…·](ğ“…·.html) der Puter Ï€[ğ“…‚](ğ“…‚.html)

Either orthographically or via some sound change or sign history, there often seems to be cases were  
Ï€ was read as t in other branches of PIE  

ğ“ƒ€ ğ“…¡ ğ“„¿ ğ“¼ ğ“ˆ—		thick [Ï€](Ï€.html)Î±Ï‡ÏÏ‚ pakhÃºs packed  
ğ“ƒ€ ğ“…¡ ğ“„¿ ğ“¼ ğ“ˆ—		thick (of fluids) Ã¾aig *Ã¾ek Estonian: paks pthick ØªØ®ÙŠÙ† taá¸µÄ«n  

this might be an artifact of scholars who were writing in Aramaic Hebrew script and mistook Ï€ for ×ª and [Ã¾](Ã¾.html) for p or something deeper was going on. Greek is already famous for having the letter Ïˆ psi, maybe historically Ï€ was pti? while far from being conclusive evidence it is north worthy that the heretic script converged the sign ğ“‡¯ (phonetic value ğ“Šªğ“ğ“‡¯) to something resembling Ï€  

ğ“ƒ€ POD  

prefixing Ï€ to all known phonetic readings of Egyptian signs would invoke dangers of the [wildcard-fallacy](wildcard-fallacy.html) if it wasn't for the hard evidence (fact) that at the time of the Greek Coptic, Ï€ was the bound article prefix of nouns.
